title: A House is Built
text:
A House is Built (1929) is the first novel of <a href="M.%20Barnard%20Eldershaw">M. Barnard Eldershaw</a>, the joint pseudonym of <a href="Marjorie%20Barnard">Marjorie Barnard</a> and <a href="Flora%20Eldershaw">Flora Eldershaw</a>. It was written as a result of their seeing an advertisement for "<a href="The%20Bulletin%20%28Australian%20periodical%29">The Bulletin</a>" prize. The novel won this prize in 1928, shared with <a href="Katharine%20Susannah%20Prichard">Katharine Susannah Prichard</a>'s "<a href="Coonardoo">Coonardoo</a>". It was originally serialised in "<a href="The%20Bulletin%20%28Australian%20periodical%29">The Bulletin</a>" under the title, "The Quartermaster".
Plot introduction.
The novel centres on James Hyde and his family. A former <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> <a href="quartermaster">quartermaster</a>, in 1837 Hyde sets up a business in <a href="History%20of%20Sydney%23Early%20Sydney">early Sydney</a>. He brings his family to Australia and would have his sons and grandsons continue his business. They are either disinclined to take up the business or more interested in the <a href="Gold%20Rush%23Australian%20gold%20rushes">Australian gold-fields</a>. His daughter Fanny has all the qualities needed to continue the family business. Constricted by <a href="gender%20stereotype">gender stereotype</a>s, Hyde, his business, and his family fall into tragedy.
